article.description: One day after the women's team snapped Connecticut's 70-game winning streak, the men's team -- with five players going all but two minutes -- stayed with Georgetown before losing 47-41 Wednesday night in the opening round of the Big East tourney.
article.headline: Despite suspensions, Villanova gives Hoyas a scare
article.linkText: Hoyas go to wire before ousting shorthanded 'Nova
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- Villanova came close to a second stunning
victory in as many days.

	   One day after the women's team snapped Connecticut's 70-game
winning streak, the men's team -- with five players going all but
two minutes -- stayed with Georgetown until the final minute, losing
46-41 Wednesday night in the opening round of the Big East
tournament.

	   "The team watched the women's game in the hotel together and we
talked a lot about the great things that have happened to
Villanova, like the 1985 national championship game,'' Wildcats
coach Jay Wright said. "We wanted today's game to be one of those,
it wouldn't be as big as that but we talked about we can do special
things at Villanova.''

	   Using a zone to try and contain Georgetown's Mike Sweetney and
trying to milk as much of every 35-second possession as possible,
the suspension-strapped Wildcats were still within two points with
1:07 to play.

	   But Gerald Riley hit a long jumper with 2 seconds left on the
shot clock to give the Hoyas (15-13) a 46-41 lead, and they added
one more point the rest of the way in the lowest scoring game in
the history of the Big East tournament.

	   Georgetown, which kept alive its streak of reaching the
quarterfinals in every Big East tournament, will face No. 11
Syracuse (23-4) on Thursday.

	   "This was a very tough game for us to play,'' Hoyas coach Craig
Esherick said. "There was an awful lot of talk about how many
scholarship players they would have, it was almost like Villanova
wasn't even going to show up so I was worried we were going to be
overconfident. Also, the way Jay has decided to play these two
games is a very difficult one to play against.''

	   Villanova (15-15), which gave then-No. 7 Pittsburgh a scare
before losing 56-54 Sunday with the same seven-man roster, had 12
players suspended last week for various lengths for unauthorized
use of a school telephone access code.

	   The suspensions were staggered so the Wildcats would have seven
players for every game, and the five starters of Randy Foye, Curtis
Sumpter, Marcus Austin, Allan Ray and Derrick Snowden were almost
enough. Those players also were suspended and will sit out either
in the NIT -- the Wildcats are eligible with a .500 record -- or next
season.

	   "We'd be more than happy to play in the NIT,'' Snowden said.
"As long as we get to play more games the whole team would be
happy with that.''

	   The loss was the fifth straight for Villanova and its sixth in
the last seven games. It also snapped a string of eight
tournament-opening wins for the Wildcats.

	   "We were hoping for the game to come down to one possession and
we had the ball,'' Wright said. "We just didn't get it done. We
though we could win. The Pitt game we didn't know what to expect,
it was the day after the suspensions were announced. This game we
had a week to prepare and we ready and thought we were going to win
it.''

	   Villanova led 23-20 at halftime, but the Wildcats managed just
two points over the first 9 1/2 minutes of the second half and the
Hoyas took the lead for good.

	   Sweetney had 12 points, two on a follow of a missed drive by
Tony Bethel that gave Georgetown a 41-35 lead with 3:36 left. Ray's
three-point play with 2:43 left made it 41-38, but Sweetney made
two free throws after he was fouled grabbing an offensive rebound
with 2:20 left.

	   Sweetney, who entered the game averaging 22.7 points, was
3-for-9 from the field as the packed-in zone limited his touches.

	   "They had three guys on Mike, and I was trying to get the ball
to Mike but I knew if we stood around and did that our shooters
would get out of rhythm,'' Esherick said. "They got our shooters
out of rhythm a couple of time and I thought a couple of times we
passed up good shots to try and get the ball to Mike.''

	   Bethel had 12 points and Riley finished with 10 for the Hoyas,
who shot 30.8 percent (16-for-52).

	   Snowden had 12 points for Villanova, while Foye and Ray each
added 10.

	   The Wildcats were able to stay even with Georgetown on the
boards as each had 31 rebounds. Sweetney had nine for the Hoyas and
Sumpter had eight for Villanova.

	   The previous record for fewest points in a game was 92 when St.
John's beat Providence 48-44 on Feb. 28, 1980, in the first Big
East tournament.
